title: Medin Zhega
text:
Medin Zhega (31 January 1946 – 12 June 2012) was an Albanian professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a> and <a href="Association%20footballer">player</a>, who played as a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a>.
Playing career.
Club.
Firstly he played for <a href="Vllaznia">Vllaznia</a> the football team of Shkodra, then he went to <a href="Dinamo%20Tirana">Dinamo Tirana</a> and he concluded his career at the team of Vllaznia. During his career he won several championships in Albania. Medin Zhega quit playing at the age of 32 on 9 September 1979.
International.
He made his debut for <a href="Albania%20national%20football%20team">Albania</a> at age 19 years and 3 months in a May 1965 <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">FIFA World Cup qualification</a> match away against <a href="Switzerland%20national%20football%20team">Switzerland</a> and earned a total of 11 caps, scoring 3 goals. His final international was a June 1971 <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201972%20qualifying">European Championship qualification</a> match against <a href="West%20Germany%20national%20football%20team">West Germany</a>.
Managerial career.
Following his playing career, Zhega became a manager and led the Albania during the 1999–2001 period. He won with <a href="Albania%20national%20football%20team">Albania</a> 
<a href="2000%20Rothmans%20International%20Tournament">2000 Rothmans International Tournament</a>. Zhega became a coach, starting his career with his former club of Vllaznia. Later Albanet Tirana in Albania, Prishtina in Kosovo and Shkëndija in Macedonia. He also coached an amateur club in Germany named SV Bad Tölz 1925.
He got the honor award "Master of Work" given by the president of Albania.
Personal life.
He was born in <a href="Shkodra">Shkodra</a>, <a href="Albania">Albania</a> 31 January 1946. In May 2011, Zhega had an accident in <a href="Toronto">Toronto</a>, Canada, which made him paraplegic and he remained in a coma for a year until he died 12 June 2012 in <a href="Tirana">Tirana</a>.
He was survived by 2 sons. One of them, Kreshnik, has also played football for <a href="Bes%C3%ABlidhja%20Lezh%C3%AB">Besëlidhja</a> and <a href="KF%20Teuta">Teuta</a> and was named assistant to coach <a href="Peter%20Pacult">Peter Pacult</a> at <a href="FK%20Kuk%C3%ABsi">FK Kukësi</a> in 2018.
